Speaker: Mr EJ HARRINSON
Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R
text: Blaxland) [11.38] - I rise to reply to the honourable member for Yarra (Mr Keon). I appreciate the joy with which Government supporters listen to statements such as those just made by the honourable member, but the honourable member for Yarra and his party attached themselves to outside groups, which brought about the need for great changes in the Labour party. When lie attempts to attack the Cahill Labour Government, and the people loyal to the Labour movement, he is undertaking a task that should rightly be left to the opponents of Labour. If he puts himself in that category, why does he not immediately take out his membership with the Liberal party? Now' let us consider what has been said by the honourable member for Yarra and the honourable member for Fawkner  and the New South Wales Government. It is all very well for the honourable members to attack Labour men, but if they have any Labour blood left in their veins they should know that there is a great tribunal in the Labour movement that is called together each year to deterMr mine relationships within the Labour party, and to decide who is to govern the Labour party. What happened in respect of Piatt ? He went before the conference, which was composed of approximately 647 delegates, and won from it a rank-and-file vote as did Bill Colboui'ne. Will the honourable member for Yarra, at this stage, condemn a rank-and-file conference of the Australian Labour party that considered all those things that he did not hesitate to bandy about the chamber this evening, and will he then say, " We shall determine who shall control the Australian Labour party"? Will he associate the same people who elected Bill Colbourne to the position that he now holds in the New South Wales branch of the party with the activities about which he has talked this evening? The people who allege that the Australian Labour party is being killed by the right honourable member for Barton (Dr Evatt) or some one else stand branded, in the eyes of every decent Labourite, as the guilty persons. Because they are so branded, they make allegations in this House. They know that they are living on borrowed time and that decent Labour people will abhor the type of tirade that they utter in this House night after night. These people who attack the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Edmonds) for defending a man who has fought against communism are lost in the wilderness. They do not know how to fight communism, because they believe in one thing onlycontrol by a minority. I say deliberately to the honourable member for Yarra that, in supporting control by a minority, as he has done, he has served the Communist cause. He has served it well because he has attempted, in his wilful way, to create an organization that will fight communism by the methods in which he believes-a n organization that could become a greater problem and a greater menace than communism itself.

Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R

Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R
text: We ' can understand why the honourable member for Yarra and his associates attack the Cahill Government. They do not say anything about the New South Wales executive of the Australian Labour party. Why are they not honest? Why did they not state that the very thing about which they complain in relation to the meeting in Queensland was discussed by the New South Wales State executive of the Australian Labour party? Why do they not point out that the meeting was held with the approval of the executive ? I challenge the honourable member and his associates to attack the executive. They should attack it if they consistently follow their principles to the limit. The honourable member for Yarra has attempted to drag a red herring across the trail by referring to the New South Wales Labour Government and members of the Australian Labour party in that State. In taking this action, he has followed the pattern of conduct that he and his associates have followed ever since they set out to capture the Labour movement.

Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R
text: Hindmarsh) [11.48] - It is amusing to hear the honourable member for Yarra (Mr Keon) refer to another honourable member as one who shivered in his shoes every time Mr. Dougherty opened the door. No one knows better than does the honourable member for Yarra the identity of the person who shivered in his shoes when Mr Dougherty opened the door and gave him the opportunity to explain why he made a secret visit to Sydney some time ago in order to obtain the services of an officer of the Australian Workers Dnion, one Bielski, in order that Bielski should be corrupted and induced to work against the organization that paid his salary in an endeavour to defeat Mr Davis in a ballot for the position of secretary of the Victorian branch of the union. Mr Dougherty gave the honourable member for Yarra, who is the person concerned, an opportunity to meet Mr Bielski in his office in order to substantiate the denial that the honourable member had made in relation to Bielski. Mr Bielski was then able to reveal other interesting facts concerning the honourable member for Yarra, and no doubt it is because this little plan came unstuck that the honourable member for Yarra and his friends are now so bitterly opposed to Mr Dougherty. Speaker: Mr HOLT
Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R
text: On the 25th A u g u s t last, the honourable member for B l a x l and (Mr . E . James H a r r is o n ) asked, me the following q u e s t i o n :Has the Minister for Labour and National Service yet considered the report of the Chief Conciliation Commissioner for the year ended the 7th October, 1954, in which the point is made that many industrial disagreements have, as their genesis, the meaning of words and phrases used in awards? If so, can he say if any action is contemplated that will make provision for a Conciliation Commissioner entertaining an application for the interpretation of any section of an award operating within his assignment in the first instance? I then undertook to give the question some f u r the r t h o u g h t , and have since been cons i d e r in g it , and an almost i d e n t it i o n w h i c h was asked in another place. I now in for m the honourable member as follows:The comments made by the Chief Conciliation Commissioner in his annual report for the period Sth October, 1953, to 7th October, 1954. have been noted for consideration. The interpretation of an award or order is at present a matter for a single judge of the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. However, the constitutional position of the court was challenged in recent proceedings in the High Court, in which judgment has been reserved. In the circumstances, the honourable member for Blaxland will no doubt agree that it would be premature at the present juncture to make any decision on the question of policy which he raised.

Speaker: Sir ERIC HARRISON
Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R
text: On Augus t the honourable Hunter (Mr James ) asked the P r i m e Minister the following question:Is the Prime Minister aware of the serious deterioration in the coal industry, due to fires, subsidences and otlier causes? latest mine to be affected is the Aberdare Extended Colliery. It is now proposed to work only a quarter of that mine. A committee has been set up to investigate the matter of stowage, but that committee has no statutory autliority. The Joint Coal Board has representation on the committee, but the coal-owners can veto any proposal for stowage. In view of thoso facts wiU the Prime Minister confer with the New South Wales Government with a view to setting up a statutory committee with authority to compel coal-owners to use the stowage method, in order to preserve the coal industry for the future of the nation ? The P r i m e Minister has f u r n is h e d the following reply:I am aware of the special problem existing on the Cessnock coal-field and particularly in the Aberdare Extended Colliery, which is at present experiencing considerable mining difficulties due to movement of the strata and subsequent distortion of the mine area. Very little can be done, according to present mining knowledge, to arrest this particular trouble in any section of a mine once it commences. Stowage experiments at present being conducted may disclose a means of reducing the trouble, but it is unlikely that anything arising from these experiments will lead to a remedy for the situation at the Aberdare Extended Colliery. The Government does not propose to disturb the present arrangement for stowage experiments under which all collieries in the Greta Seam are voluntarily contributing to a fund for the purpose of financing such experiments. The Joint Coal Board considers the present arrangement to be the most suitable for the time being in view of the experimental nature of the work. I understand also that the present Minister for Mines in New c a l quesSouth Wales has stated that no necessity exists at the present time for the establishment of a statutory body to conduct these ex|>eriments. The Minister for National Development and the Joint Coal Board are paying particular attention to ensure the security of employment of any mineworkers who may he displaced from their present employment if any further portions of the Aberdare Extended Colliery become unworkable. The board proposes, amongst other things, to have an early discussion with the company which operates the mine regarding alternative methods of working the mine and absorbing the men. Naturally the company will be concerned to preserve its assets and will be taking whatever steps it can to alleviate the position. IRON AND STEEL. COAL. AUSTRALIAN MILITARY FORCES.  Army, upon notice I. How many members of the defence personnel who have applied are unable to obtain homes at Puckapunyal, Victoria? 2. What action is being taken to provide homes for married service personnel at Puckapunyal, and when are those seeking houses likely to obtain tbem?

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Title: DEPUTYSPEAKE R
text: The answers honourable member's questions are as follows:1. As at the (ith October, 1955, there were fourteen officers, 32 warrant officers and sergeants, and 5(i rank-and-file members of the Australian Military Forces stationed at Puckapunyal recorded as having applied for married quarters there but for whom no such quarters were available. 2. Since the World War II . , some 2,103 married quarters have been provided for Army personnel throughout Australia. At Puckapunyal, 415 have been built since 1949. There is a need for married quarters for Army personnel at various places throughout the Commonwealth. Quarters for single members, storage facilities and other works are also urgently required. The importance of married quarters is f u l ly recognized and their provision has been accorded a very high priority in the Army's works programmes. Our ability to provide additional houses at Puckapunyal is, of course, subject to the overall capacity of senting the building industry in Australia and the competing claims upon it by the Army and all other Government departments and public authorities, both State and Federal. I would remind the honourable member that, in the Housing Agreement, signed by Mr Chifley wit h the States in 1945, there was a provision for a percentage of the houses built under that Agreement to be allocated by the State authorities to servicemen and ex-servicemen. In the negotiations which are at present current with the States, it is hoped that that principle will continue in force in the new agreement. And, in consultation with my colleague, the Minister for National Development, I shall be taking up with the State authorities the possibility of providing houses for serving members in the Permanent Forces, in accordance with the original intention of the Housing Agreement. ALUMINIUM.

Speaker: Mr OSBORNE
Title: SUPREMECOURT OF PAPUAANDNE W
text: the Minister reprethe Attorney-General, upon notice I. Is it considered that citizens of Papua and New Guinea should be entitled to assert ancl protect their rights as citizens against the Crown by action in the law courts ? 2. Is it a fact that the Supreme Court of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea has no authority to entertain the suit of a citizen against the Commonwealth ? 3. Did counsel for the Commonwealth, at the hearing of a suit recently brought against the Commonwealth in the High Court by J. L . Chipper and Company Limited, a company incorporated in the Territory, argue that the High Court had no jurisdiction to hear the suit, and was the case thereupon settled to a less advantage to the plaintiff tlian if the suit had proceeded and been won by the plaintiff? 4. If the answers are in the affirmative, will the Attorney-General institute legislation to correct this anomaly?

Speaker: Sir ERIC HARRISON
Title: SUPREMECOURT OF PAPUAANDNE W
text: The Attorney General has supplied the following answers to the honourable member's questions :The High Court action to which the honourable member refers, and which was brought by JL . Chipper & Company Limited against the Commonwealth, comprised both claims by the company and countev-clairas hy the Commonwealth. When it came before Taylor J., candour required the Commonwealth to point out that, in the present state of the authoriwith ties, there was some doubt whether or not the High Court had jurisdiction in the matter. The honourable member will appreciate the fact that consent of the parties cannot confer jurisdiction. Having heard the evidence, Taylor - A stated that the case was beset with many difficult questions on both sides, and that the matter appeared to him to be one which ought to be settled if it were at all possible. He offered to discuss the matter counsel in chambers, and advantage was taken of this offer. The matter was subsequently settled by consent, but I do not think the doubts as to the court's jurisdiction had any influence on the settlement. The questions of law and policy raised by the honourable member's questions are at present under consideration.
